beyond the leg bones, but at a higher level (40 to 60 centimetres above the floor), were 15 bronze arrows (ID: 373). This could suggest the precence of some element of perishable material (body-shield? quiver? Wodden ledge?)

properties.note:
The border and handle (attached by three rivet.s) are decorated with a raised reticulated pattern, recalling turner's work, which is shown in more detail on the lamp (/) [ID: 607].Except for its shallower form this vessel recalls those found in the building west of the Palace at Knossos, and another, of which the rim only was preserved, from the cemetery at Phaestos.
The decoration in the present case, however, is of a more mechanical character.

The knobbed upright projection on each of the horizontal handles recurs in 14d [ID: 386]. This is a common feature of Minoan bronzebowls, the knobbed projection being perhaps found useful for winding stuff round when lifting the heated vessel.This is probably a cooking pot.
properties.original_description: Two-handled bronze pan with upward curving sides (see notes for full description)

properties.note: The handles, each attached by four rivets, are of the same type with upright projections.
properties.original_description: Two-handled bronze pan (see notes for full description)

properties.note: Small bronze pan with solid handle sloping upwards and topped by a knob serving the same purpose as that described under 14c [ID: 385]; similar vessels were found in Tomb 36 below [ID: 431] , in the necropolis of Phaestos, and in a tomb in the Lower Town of Mycenae. These must be regarded as small frying pans.
properties.original_description: Small bronze pan with solid handle (see notes for full description)

properties.note:
Its border shows ahatched decoration like that of the bason (14b) [ID: 384]. It is provided with a long handle with a tapering end convenient for insertion into the chinks of walls.
Its most remarkable feature, however, is a chain attached to a knob at the base of the handle, consisting of three long links ending in a loop, from which doubtless hung some kind of
trimmer for the wick. The lamp is quite unique.
properties.original_description: Bronze lamp (for full description, see notes)

properties.note: Large bronze jug (35 cm high and 35 cm in diameter) with two handles—one attached to the neck and shoulders, the other to the lowest section—of a type also found at Palaikastro, in the Palace of Hagia Triada, and in a tomb at Phaestos; apart from the rim and base, the vase is constructed from three overlapping sections joined by small rivets, and in overall form resembles the copper jugs from the fourth shaft-grave at Mycenae, though those were made in one piece due to copper’s greater malleability.

properties.note: The collar and body of this are formed of three plates riveted together. The vessel itself, with its upright handle attached to the rim and its horizontal handle below, resembles the bronze jug already described under No. 14g [ID: 382]. The present vase, however, is distinguished by a decorative adjunct of great delicacy. Two cockle-shells or small scallops in relief are attached to the two extremities of the upright handle, the upper of these being much smaller than the other. Cockles in relief, as an adornment of clay and porcelain vases, occur already in the Middle Minoan Period. The vase had been considerably distorted by the pressure of the superincumbent earth.
properties.original_description: Bronze ewer (see notes for full description)

properties.note: The two handles of which are provided with knobbed upright projections, like the vessels described under No. 14c, etc [ID 385, 386]. This pan was a good deal crushed, but is reproduced in its original outlines in fig. 52. A bronze pan of similar type occurred in Tomb 8 at Phaestos. Two swords were found in the same tomb.

The upper edge of the pan has been somewhat beaten out, and a flat circular plate welded onto this, which is adorned with spiral reliefs. (See fig. 55.) A plain "frying-pan" of similar type has already been described under No. 14e [ID 392] and another was found at Phaestos, also in Tomb 8.
There are two holes in the socket for rivets, and signs of a joint are visible along one side.

properties.note:
Bronze sword of pointed form, for thrusting, with ivory pommel; length without pommel 94.5 centimetres, with pommel 95.5 centimetres. The ivory pommel, of which a small part was decayed, is fixed by a cross rivet of bronze, and round its base is a gold collar. The wooden mounting of the hilt was secured on each side by five large gold-plated studs. 

A minute but very fine decoration, consisting of double rows of connected spirals in relief, runs along the sides of the hilt and the central rib of the blade. (Fig. 58, and fig. 109, 36b.) The entire sword is shown in fig. 112b, below.
properties.original_description: Bronze sword of pointed form, for thrusting, with ivory pommel (see note for full description)

properties.note:
Bronze sword of pointed form, for thrusting, with ivory pommel; length without pommel 94.5 centimetres, with pommel 95.5 centimetres. The ivory pommel, of which a small part was decayed, is fixed by a cross rivet of bronze, and round its base is a gold collar. The wooden mounting of the hilt was secured on each side by five large gold-plated studs. 

A minute but very fine decoration, consisting of double rows of connected spirals in relief, runs along the sides of the hilt and the central rib of the blade. (Fig. 58, and fig. 109, 36b.) The entire sword is shown in fig. 112b, below.
properties.original_description: Bronze sword of pointed form, for thrusting, with ivory pommel (see note for full description)

properties.note:
Short bronze sword, also for thrusting, with agate pommel. Length with pommel 61 centimetres. The pommel, which is of beautifully banded translucent agate, is 4.4 centimetres in diameter, and is perforated in order to be fixed to the hilt with a bronze rivet. Its base is surrounded by a gold collar. The hilt on both sides is covered with gold plates attached by five gold-plated rivets. These plates seem to have originally had a thin wooden backing, and minute rivet holes for attachment to these are seen along the borders of the oval opening near the lower end of each plate.

The plates are divided by a curved moulding into an upper and lower field, each engraved with very spirited designs of lions and wild goats. (Fig. 59.) The lower field shows a lion and a Cretan wild goat or agrimi, looking back at each other, the agrimi in the act of springing, the lion as if starting in pursuit. On the borders above and below are indications of rocks. In the upper field we see the sequel to the other. The lion has gripped the hindquarters of the he-goat with one paw, arresting its flight, while, with the other raised, he prepares to bring it finally to the ground. We have here the same rocky landscape, the rocks above represented in a downward position in accordance with the conventional method of perspective constantly employed by the Minoan artists. From the ground below the lion rises a bell-shaped flower, apparently a tulip, such as still grows wild in the Cretan valleys. The design itself, in spite of the cramped conditions under which it was composed, is of singular force and naturalism, and the unavoidable effacement of part of the outlines by the discs of the rivet holes has been dealt with in such a way as to preserve the more important features. The sides of the hilt and the central rib of the blade are covered, as in the case of the preceding sword, with double rows of spirals of microscopic fineness in relief. Remains of linen tissue, probably belonging to the shroud, are seen attached to parts of the blade [ID: 628].
properties.original_description: Short bronze sword, also for thrusting, with agate pommel (see notes for full description)

properties.note: Remains of linen tissue (from sowrd zp_36i [ID: 428] ) probably belonging to the shroud, are seen attached to parts of the blade.

Gold necklace, consisting of 18 beads of thin gold plate, repeating an embossed design derived from a double argonaut (rovyo argonanta). The design resembles that presented by the gold necklace found in Grave No. 7 [ID: 601] , but in the present case the relief is finer. As noticed above, under No. 7, necklaces with gold beads showing a similar pattern were found in tombs at Phaestos and elsewhere. One such occurred in the dromos of a tomb (No. 8) of the Lower Town at Mycenae, containing a fibula of the early fiddle-bow type.
properties.original_description: Gold necklace, consisting of 18 beads of thin gold plate (see notes for full description)

properties.note: Agate lentoid bead with intaglio in a fine bold style showing a horned sheep, perhaps a mouflon, attached by a cord to a column with a spiral shaft. In front of it is a spray (fig. 61). The spiral column is shown on another contemporary intaglio, standing on a base with two lion supporters. It seems probable that the present device has a religious signification, and that the animal here must be regarded as sacred to a divinity.

This vase is remarkable for its fine style of decoration. On the upper surface is a raised decoration like a Mycenaean shield, and rosettes recalling those in a similar position on the large stirrup-vase from the Royal Villa. The beautiful foliation around the shoulders, with its many times reduplicated edging, is a ceramic adaptation from the foliated chasing of bronze vessels, such as the bowl from the North-West Building at Knossos. 
The same reduplication accompanies the foliated band around the shoulders of a magnificent amphora of the Palace Style, from the Royal Tomb described below. The trefoils on the lower part of the vase are also frequently found on vases of the Palace Style. These comparisons may be taken to show that the fabric of the fine vase with which we are dealing must be referred to the latest Palace Period of Knossos. 
The style belongs to Late Minoan II.
Resembles the type 6b. [ID: 377]

properties.note:
Round the neck is a slightly raised ring. The faces of the flask show concentric circles, and on either side is a vertical line of triangles, the base of one resting on the apex of another. These clay flasks are rare in Crete, but are of frequent occurrence in Cypro-Mycenaean interments, e.g. Enkomi, Tomb 45; Kurion, etc. 

Faience flasks of similar shape were made in Egypt (an example was found in the Enkomi tomb referred to above). The decoration of concentric circles recurs on the Cypriote specimens, and as the superposed triangles are also a Cypriote detail, it seems probable that the present flask was imported from Cyprus.

properties.note:
Gold necklace of forty beads with triple perforation, showing double argonaut design in repousse work [...] As stated above, it is essentially a duplicated argonaut (Argo argonauta), though it has been combined with the octopus motif, and in some varieties the number of tentacles is, in consequence, raised from six to eight.

The source also mention some comprisons: Another similar necklace was found in Grave 36. Similar gold necklaces were found in the chamber-tombs near Phaestos (Savignoni, Necropoli di Phaestos, p. 99, fig. 58), and others were obtained at Mycenae from the tombs of the lower town (Tsountas, E0. Ap. 1888, pl. ix. 4), in some cases showing eight tentacles (Fig. 20). Gold beads of a necklace from Pit-Cave (No. 7), instead of six (Karo in Daremberg et Saglio, Dictionnaire des Antiquités, art. Monile, fig. 5125, and Savignoni loc. cit.). Another from a contemporary tomb at Argos is published by Vollgraff (Bull. de Corr. hell. 1904, p. 383, fig. 15). A mould for a similar bead, said to have been found in Asia Minor, is in the Berlin Museum (Furtw. u. Loeschke, Myh. Vasen, p. 34, fig. 22). [...] the argonaut by itself, representing half of the present design with three tentacles, occurs on gold plates and glass-paste beads from Mycenae (J. H. S. xxiv. 324, fig. 1a; and ’E^. ’Ap’. 1887, pl. xiii. 2, 3), and also on the mould found by Schliemann (Mycenae, p. 107, fig. 102). The argonaut, which at Knossos is a favourite motif of the beautiful faience fabric of the close of the Third Middle-Minoan Period, was taken over, probably from this source, together with similar rockwork onto the painted ware of the succeeding Palace Style. It also appears on wall paintings, e.g. in those of the room by the Megaron at Mycenae.
string probabily not conserved. For a full description see note element 363
anello in oro con castone su cui è rappresentata una sfinge

The upturned end recalls the Minoan boat on a seal- impression from the Temple Repository of the Palace at Knossos {Report, p. 58, fig. 36).
The two holes at either end of the hollow part of the boat possibly served for a lid, and the flat surface of the raised rim corroborates this view. In this case we have here a casket similar to the well-known duck-shaped boxes of Egypt.

properties.note:
Female figure of black steatite perforated through the shoulders for suspension. It has the usual Late Minoan (Mycenaean) flounces and cross grooves on the upper part of the body.
This figure seems to be of the nature of an amulet, and may be taken to represent the great Goddess of Minoan Crete, later known as Rhea. Other small steatite figures of the same kind, perforated for suspension, have been found in Crete. Another similar amulet of dark steatite, now in the Ashmolean Museum, is said to have been found in the Lebanon.

properties.note:
The midrib of the blade is flattish and slightly rounded. The hilt showed some of the wooden handle [ID: 671] adhering and has two rivets. 
In its general type, the sword corresponds to 42a [ID: 441] , 43a [ID: 442] , 55a [ID: 460], and 36i [ID: 428] , but there seems to have been no tang at the extremity of the hilt.
